channel.title: BBC News - Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Over-60s with only virtual contact 'more lonely'
item.description: UK-US research finds old people who used only telephone and online communication were more lonely.

item.title: Amazon Bitcoin job ad boosts cryptocurrency surge
item.description: News Amazon is hiring a digital-currency expert has helped boost the value of Bitcoin.

item.title: Shares in Chinese online tutoring firms slump after shake-up
item.description: It is one of the biggest ever overhauls of China's $120bn private tutoring industry.

item.title: Tencent shares slide after Beijing crackdown on music rights
item.description: China's market watchdog said the technology giant broke the country's anti-competition rules.

item.title: Face palm: When the emoji you want doesn't exist
item.description: There are about 3,000 emojis to choose from but what happens when the one you want isn't there?

item.title: Zuckerberg wants Facebook to become online 'metaverse'
item.description: CEO wants users to work, game and communicate in a virtual world, often using VR headsets.

item.title: Printer ink pricier than champagne finds Which?
item.description: According to a Which survey a pint of printer ink could cost up to £1,300.

item.title: Ransomware key to unlock customer data from REvil attack
item.description: The gang behind the attack had previously asked for $70m to access the stolen files.

item.title: AI breakthrough could spark medical revolution
item.description: A program has been used to predict the structures of nearly every protein in the human body.

item.title: Gun owners' fears after firearms dealer data breach
item.description: Thousands of records from the popular shotgun and rifle sales site Guntrader were posted to the dark web.

item.title: Twitter and Snap add users as restrictions ease
item.description: The social media companies passed analysts' expectations with their latest financial update.

item.title: Vineyards set to go high tech with smart systems
item.description: Changing climate conditions and water shortages see some Australian wine growers turn to technology.

item.title: Beach rover picks up cigarette butts and other tech news
item.description: Jen Copestake looks at some of the best technology news stories of the week.

item.title: Cyber-flashing: 'I get explicit messages every day'
item.description: Influencer Elle Edwards lets us inside her DMs to show the extent of sexual abuse faced by women online.

item.title: Spyware: The software that watches you
item.description: BBC’s cyber reporter, Joe Tidy, agreed to be spied on to understand the spyware experience further.

item.title: Custom glasses: Will 3D-printing change our eyewear?
item.description: Eyewear can be more tailored to an individual’s face producing a better fit and reduce overstocking.

item.title: Why remote working leaves us vulnerable to cyber-attacks
item.description: Experts warn working from home has led to complacency over security protocols

item.title: Covid: Will lockdown change England's new tech habits?
item.description: The pandemic brought about big changes in the way people use tech - the question is will they last?

item.title: What does a future-proofed home look like?
item.description: The technology exists to make homes more resilient to extreme weather, but it can be expensive.

item.title: Zoomtown-on-Sea? The lure of a new life on the coast
item.description: Remote working meant the Lancaster family could live anywhere - they found their sea view in Scarborough.

item.title: Pegasus scandal: Are we all becoming unknowing spies?
item.description: We may be stepping into a world in which we are all spies - and at the same time are all spied on.

item.title: Finding 'Grace': Murder, DNA and ancestry
item.description: How a novel use of DNA and ancestry websites is helping police uncover clues in cold case murders.

item.title: Why was my tweet about football labelled abusive?
item.description: A BBC journalist sets out to discover how Twitter moderates posts after he was banned from the platform.
